content.text: Keratitis is inflammation of the cornea, the transparent front part of the eye that covers the iris, pupil, and anterior chamber. It can be infectious or non-infectious. Infectious keratitis is an ophthalmic emergency that can lead to significant scarring, corneal perforation, and permanent vision loss if not diagnosed and treated promptly. This overview focuses on the differential diagnosis of major types of infectious keratitis.
Key Differentiating Features of Infectious Keratitis

content.text: Any patient with a suspected corneal ulcer (keratitis) requires immediate referral to an ophthalmologist. A delay in treatment can have devastating consequences for vision.

items: A thorough history focusing on risk factors (contact lenses, trauma, etc.).
Slit-lamp examination with fluorescein staining to assess the size and depth of the epithelial defect and underlying infiltrate.
Corneal scraping for smears and cultures before initiating antimicrobial therapy. This is the cornerstone of diagnosis.
Initiate broad-spectrum topical antimicrobial therapy immediately after cultures are obtained.
Therapy is intensive (e.g., hourly drops) and is tapered based on clinical response.
Never patch an eye with a suspected infectious keratitis, as this can create a favorable environment for bacterial growth.

The use of topical corticosteroids is highly controversial and should only be managed by a corneal specialist, as they can worsen certain infections (especially fungal and herpetic) if used inappropriately.
